trans-unit.source: How to: Configure Trust Between ACS and ASP.NET Web Applications Using X.509 Certificates
trans-unit.target: How to: Configure Trust Between ACS and ASP.NET Web Applications Using X.509 Certificates

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: How to: Configure Trust Between ACS and ASP.NET Web Applications Using X.509 Certificates
trans-unit.target: How to: Configure Trust Between ACS and ASP.NET Web Applications Using X.509 Certificates

trans-unit.source: Applies To
trans-unit.target: Applies To

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to configure trust between your application and <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to configure trust between your application and <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Trust is established by signing the tokens that are exchanged between your ASP.NET web application and <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: Trust is established by signing the tokens that are exchanged between your ASP.NET web application and <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Contents
trans-unit.target: Contents

trans-unit.source: Objectives
trans-unit.target: Objectives

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Summary of steps
trans-unit.target: Summary of steps

trans-unit.source: Step 1 – Navigate to the Token Signing Certificates Section
trans-unit.target: Step 1 – Navigate to the Token Signing Certificates Section

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Configure Trust Using X.509 Certificates
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Configure Trust Using X.509 Certificates

trans-unit.source: Step 3 - Review Trust-Related Attributes in web.config and the ACS Management Portal
trans-unit.target: Step 3 - Review Trust-Related Attributes in web.config and the ACS Management Portal

trans-unit.source: Objectives
trans-unit.target: Objectives

trans-unit.source: Become familiar with the trust management section on the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Become familiar with the trust management section on the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Manage trust using X.509 certificates.
trans-unit.target: Manage trust using X.509 certificates.

trans-unit.source: Verify the required configuration in web.config and on the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Verify the required configuration in web.config and on the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Establishing trust is required to properly exchange tokens between your application and <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: Establishing trust is required to properly exchange tokens between your application and <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Trust ensures that the tokens are not tampered with in transit and that they are issued by a trusted party.
trans-unit.target: Trust ensures that the tokens are not tampered with in transit and that they are issued by a trusted party.

trans-unit.source: For ASP.NET web applications trust is managed using X.509 certificates and is based on the configuration of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal and the web.config configuration.
trans-unit.target: For ASP.NET web applications trust is managed using X.509 certificates and is based on the configuration of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal and the web.config configuration.

trans-unit.source: Summary of Steps
trans-unit.target: Summary of Steps

trans-unit.source: To establish and manage trust between an ASP.NET web application and <token>secondref_acs</token> follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To establish and manage trust between an ASP.NET web application and <token>secondref_acs</token> follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Step 1 - Navigate to the Token Signing Certificates Section
trans-unit.target: Step 1 - Navigate to the Token Signing Certificates Section

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Configure Trust Using X.509 Certificates
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Configure Trust Using X.509 Certificates

trans-unit.source: Step 3 - Review Trust-Related Attributes in web.config and the ACS Management Portal
trans-unit.target: Step 3 - Review Trust-Related Attributes in web.config and the ACS Management Portal

trans-unit.source: Step 1 – Navigate to the Token Signing Certificates Section
trans-unit.target: Step 1 – Navigate to the Token Signing Certificates Section

trans-unit.source: This step shows how to navigate to the trust management section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: This step shows how to navigate to the trust management section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: To navigate to the section related to trust management on the Management Portal
trans-unit.target: To navigate to the section related to trust management on the Management Portal

trans-unit.source: In the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal, click <ui>Relying party applications</ui>.
trans-unit.target: In the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal, click <ui>Relying party applications</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Click a relying party application.
trans-unit.target: Click a relying party application.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Edit Relying Party Application</ui> page, scroll down to the <ui>Token Signing Certificates</ui> section.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Edit Relying Party Application</ui> page, scroll down to the <ui>Token Signing Certificates</ui> section.

trans-unit.source: Select a certificate.
trans-unit.target: Select a certificate.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Configure Trust Using X.509 Certificates
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Configure Trust Using X.509 Certificates

trans-unit.source: This step shows how to configure and manage the trust between <token>secondref_acs</token> and an ASP.NET web application using an X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: This step shows how to configure and manage the trust between <token>secondref_acs</token> and an ASP.NET web application using an X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: Use an X.509 certificate signing credential if you are using the Windows® Identity Foundation (WIF) in your relying party application.
trans-unit.target: Use an X.509 certificate signing credential if you are using the Windows® Identity Foundation (WIF) in your relying party application.

trans-unit.source: To configure and manage trust using an X.509 certificate
trans-unit.target: To configure and manage trust using an X.509 certificate

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Certificates and keys</ui> and then select an X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Certificates and keys</ui> and then select an X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Edit Token Signing Certificate or Key</ui> page, provide the following values:
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Edit Token Signing Certificate or Key</ui> page, provide the following values:

trans-unit.source: <ui>Name</ui>: An arbitrary name of your choice.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Name</ui>: An arbitrary name of your choice.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Type</ui>: <ui>X.509 Certificate</ui>.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Type</ui>: <ui>X.509 Certificate</ui>.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Certificate</ui>: To use the certificate that <token>secondref_acs</token> creates by default, no action is required.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Certificate</ui>: To use the certificate that <token>secondref_acs</token> creates by default, no action is required.

trans-unit.source: You can also upload your own X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: You can also upload your own X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: The certificate should be password protected.
trans-unit.target: The certificate should be password protected.

trans-unit.source: It usually has a .pfx extension.
trans-unit.target: It usually has a .pfx extension.

trans-unit.source: when uploading your own X.509 certificate.Provide the pfx file password in the <ui>Password</ui> text box
trans-unit.target: when uploading your own X.509 certificate.Provide the pfx file password in the <ui>Password</ui> text box

trans-unit.source: <ui>Password</ui>: If you use the default certificate, no action is required.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Password</ui>: If you use the default certificate, no action is required.

trans-unit.source: If you upload a certificate, the certificate should be password protected.
trans-unit.target: If you upload a certificate, the certificate should be password protected.

trans-unit.source: Enter the .pfx file password in the <ui>Password</ui> text box.
trans-unit.target: Enter the .pfx file password in the <ui>Password</ui> text box.

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Save</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Save</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Get an X.509 Certificate
trans-unit.target: Get an X.509 Certificate

trans-unit.source: There are several ways to get an X.509 certificate for token signing or encryption.
trans-unit.target: There are several ways to get an X.509 certificate for token signing or encryption.

trans-unit.source: The method you will use depends on your requirements and the tools available to your organization.
trans-unit.target: The method you will use depends on your requirements and the tools available to your organization.

trans-unit.source: Local Certification Authority
trans-unit.target: Local Certification Authority

trans-unit.source: If your organization has deployed a certification authority (CA), such as Active Directory Certificate Services (AD CS), you can request an X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: If your organization has deployed a certification authority (CA), such as Active Directory Certificate Services (AD CS), you can request an X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: You might need to contact your certification authority administrator for instructions or permissions.
trans-unit.target: You might need to contact your certification authority administrator for instructions or permissions.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Active Directory Certificate Services, see <externalLink><linkText>Active Directory Certificate Services</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=208371</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=208371).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Active Directory Certificate Services, see <externalLink><linkText>Active Directory Certificate Services</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=208371</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=208371).

trans-unit.source: Commercial Certification Authority
trans-unit.target: Commercial Certification Authority

trans-unit.source: You can purchase an X.509 certificate from a commercial certification authority, such as Verisign.
trans-unit.target: You can purchase an X.509 certificate from a commercial certification authority, such as Verisign.

trans-unit.source: Since this is a Labs release, it is recommended that you use your local certification authority (if available) or generate a self-signed certificate (see below).
trans-unit.target: Since this is a Labs release, it is recommended that you use your local certification authority (if available) or generate a self-signed certificate (see below).

trans-unit.source: Generate a Self-Signed Certificate
trans-unit.target: Generate a Self-Signed Certificate

trans-unit.source: You can use software to generate your own self-signed certificate to use with <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: You can use software to generate your own self-signed certificate to use with <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: While this is typically recommended only for testing purposes, this can be done by anyone without access to a local CA or payment to a commercial CA.
trans-unit.target: While this is typically recommended only for testing purposes, this can be done by anyone without access to a local CA or payment to a commercial CA.

trans-unit.source: If you are running Windows, you can download MakeCert.exe as part of the <externalLink><linkText>Windows SDK</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=84091</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=84091) and use this to generate a certificate.
trans-unit.target: If you are running Windows, you can download MakeCert.exe as part of the <externalLink><linkText>Windows SDK</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=84091</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=84091) and use this to generate a certificate.

trans-unit.source: Export a Self-Signed Certificate
trans-unit.target: Export a Self-Signed Certificate

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to export a self-signed certificate, see <link xlink:href="b75ed5c7-ca81-44a2-8d8d-6a63399f87dd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Certificates and Keys</link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to export a self-signed certificate, see <link xlink:href="b75ed5c7-ca81-44a2-8d8d-6a63399f87dd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Certificates and Keys</link>.

trans-unit.source: Step 3 - Review Trust-Related Attributes in web.config and the ACS Management Portal
trans-unit.target: Step 3 - Review Trust-Related Attributes in web.config and the ACS Management Portal

trans-unit.source: This step shows how to validate trust-related configuration attributes in your ASP.NET web application’s web.config.
trans-unit.target: This step shows how to validate trust-related configuration attributes in your ASP.NET web application’s web.config.

trans-unit.source: To verify trust-related configurations in your ASP.NET web application web.config
trans-unit.target: To verify trust-related configurations in your ASP.NET web application web.config

trans-unit.source: Open the web.config file for your ASP.NET web application.
trans-unit.target: Open the web.config file for your ASP.NET web application.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the <ui>audiencesUris</ui> node and verify that the value of its child <ui>add</ui> node is the same as that value that you entered in the <ui>Realm</ui> property field of the <ui>Edit Relying Party</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the <ui>audiencesUris</ui> node and verify that the value of its child <ui>add</ui> node is the same as that value that you entered in the <ui>Realm</ui> property field of the <ui>Edit Relying Party</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Relying party applications</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Relying party applications</ui>.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Replying Party Applications</ui> page, click the desired application.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Replying Party Applications</ui> page, click the desired application.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Edit Relying Party Application</ui> page, review the <ui>Realm</ui> attribute.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Edit Relying Party Application</ui> page, review the <ui>Realm</ui> attribute.
